title: How to Bake Tsoureki (Greek Sweet Bread)

steps.headline: Make the spice water by boiling 1 stick of cinnamon and 5 bay leaves  into a cup of water for 15 minutes.
Let cool for 10 minutes and add yeast and 1 teaspoon of sugar to spice water.
Heat can of milk in saucepan on a low flame, adding one can’s worth of water followed soon after by the butter.
Beat 7 of the eggs and sugar in a separate, large bowl.
Add the milk mixture and the yeast mixture to the egg/sugar bowl.
Grind masticha and machlepi in a mortar and pestle with teaspoon of sugar until fine, sticky paste.
Mix ground masticha and machlepi into the growing mixture.
steps.description: The masticha and machlepi will be difficult to remove entirely from the mortar and pestle, but try to extricate as much as possible.

steps.headline: Stop to revel in the use of two ingredients never previously encountered.
steps.description: Prepare to use this in a later argument with friends about being more “cultured” than they.

steps.headline: Slowly add flour to the mixture, kneading with hands until dough is soft and slightly sticky.
steps.description: Resist urge to add extra flour, as the mixture is supposed to feel less cohesive than normal bread dough.

steps.headline: Wrap coin in aluminum foil and knead it into the dough.
Place into a pie tin or simply let rise.
steps.description: The shape must be circular, but there is no exact method of placement, so design as you so choose.

steps.headline: Mix the remaining two eggs with sesame seeds and then lightly brush the mixture onto the top of the dough once it has risen.
Bake at 350 degrees for 5 minutes.
Lower oven to 250 degrees and let bake for 45 minutes or until golden brown.
Place finished (and cooled) Vaselopita onto large plate.
Have the primary caregiver in the house place money (around $20-40 dollars) onto center of table near Vaselopita.
steps.description: This is the prize money for whoever finds the coin in their slice.

steps.headline: Carve a cross shape into the top (the ritual begins with a remembrance of Christ).
Spin Vaselopita three times (also a religious reference, this time to the Trinity).
Cut Vaselopita into equal sections, in this order:
steps.description: Christou (For the Church) Spitiou (For the House) Thoulia (For the Work) Nikoukidi (For the ‘Man’ of the House) Nikoukida (For the ‘Woman’ of the House) Bethiou (One slice for each of the children starting with the oldest. Guests are usually included in this section. Some families include slices for pets as well!)

steps.headline: Search pieces for the coin.
steps.description: Whoever finds the coin wins the prize money!

steps.headline: Spend the prize money on something frivolous that makes you happy!
steps.description: The point of the whole ritual is to start the year off with a hopeful feeling in your heart and a smile on your face! The money CANNOT be used on something necessary or solemn in nature! The object the money purchases must be an instrument of joy. For instance, if the dime is found in the Work piece, the money should be used to buy things to decorate your office. If a pet should win the coin, go buy him/her a new toy or a few treats!

steps.headline: The only situation in which the money is used seriously is if the Church wins.
steps.description: The money should be donated the next time the family goes to church (which is usually later that day if you are Greek .

steps.headline: Keep the coin in a safe place for the next year and do not spend it!
steps.description: The coin will be your good luck charm for the next 365 days!

text: Steps Make the spice water by boiling 1 stick of cinnamon and 5 bay leaves  into a cup of water for 15 minutes.  Let cool for 10 minutes and add yeast and 1 teaspoon of sugar to spice water. Set aside. Heat can of milk in saucepan on a low flame, adding one can’s worth of water followed soon after by the butter. Allow butter to melt. Beat 7 of the eggs and sugar in a separate, large bowl.  Add the milk mixture and the yeast mixture to the egg/sugar bowl. Stir slowly. Grind masticha and machlepi in a mortar and pestle with teaspoon of sugar until fine, sticky paste.  Mix ground masticha and machlepi into the growing mixture. The masticha and machlepi will be difficult to remove entirely from the mortar and pestle, but try to extricate as much as possible. Stop to revel in the use of two ingredients never previously encountered. Prepare to use this in a later argument with friends about being more “cultured” than they. Slowly add flour to the mixture, kneading with hands until dough is soft and slightly sticky. Resist urge to add extra flour, as the mixture is supposed to feel less cohesive than normal bread dough. Wrap coin in aluminum foil and knead it into the dough.  Place into a pie tin or simply let rise. The shape must be circular, but there is no exact method of placement, so design as you so choose. Mix the remaining two eggs with sesame seeds and then lightly brush the mixture onto the top of the dough once it has risen.  Bake at 350 degrees for 5 minutes.  Lower oven to 250 degrees and let bake for 45 minutes or until golden brown.  The Luck Ritual Place finished (and cooled) Vaselopita onto large plate.  Have the primary caregiver in the house place money (around $20-40 dollars) onto center of table near Vaselopita. This is the prize money for whoever finds the coin in their slice. Carve a cross shape into the top (the ritual begins with a remembrance of Christ).  Spin Vaselopita three times (also a religious reference, this time to the Trinity).  Cut Vaselopita into equal sections, in this order: Christou (For the Church) Spitiou (For the House) Thoulia (For the Work) Nikoukidi (For the ‘Man’ of the House) Nikoukida (For the ‘Woman’ of the House) Bethiou (One slice for each of the children starting with the oldest. Guests are usually included in this section. Some families include slices for pets as well!) Search pieces for the coin. Whoever finds the coin wins the prize money! Spend the prize money on something frivolous that makes you happy! The point of the whole ritual is to start the year off with a hopeful feeling in your heart and a smile on your face! The money CANNOT be used on something necessary or solemn in nature! The object the money purchases must be an instrument of joy. For instance, if the dime is found in the Work piece, the money should be used to buy things to decorate your office. If a pet should win the coin, go buy him/her a new toy or a few treats! The only situation in which the money is used seriously is if the Church wins. The money should be donated the next time the family goes to church (which is usually later that day if you are Greek . Keep the coin in a safe place for the next year and do not spend it! The coin will be your good luck charm for the next 365 days!
